Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Exploiting the Naturalness of Software

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration: A study of software code has revealed a surprising result: that software code may be just as (if not more) "natural" as natural language itself (e.g., English) in that code is highly predictable and repetitive; statistical natural language techniques may be applied quite competently for some software engineering tasks. For example, N-grams may be quite effective at suggestion and completion tasks in code. The evidence supports further exploration of the applicability of statistical NLP techniques and tools to software development activities and processes. The project explores the feasibility of establishing a scientific basis and tools for a variety of code-level software engineering functions -- including natural language summarization, code retrieval, software question answering, automated code completion, and assistive tools for disabled developers to support software engineering, forming not only a new and important domain for further research in NLP, but also a totally new approach to software development.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Background: This project began with the observation that "natural" code, written by programmers to solve "natural" problems, was highly repetitive and predictable, in ways similiar to natural language. Based on this observation, we were eager to explore how statistical NLP methods, (which are very succesful for speech recognition and automated translation) could be applied to help programmers.  This EAGER was granted to establish a collaboration between software engineering reserchers at UC Davis and NLP researchers CMU.

Collaboration: Based on this grant, we established a strong collaboration,  with colleagues William Cohen and Roni Rosenfeld at Carnegie Mellon. Prior to this grant, to our knowledge, there had never been such a strong collaboration with software engineeing researchers  and NLP researchers. SE researchers were largely unaware of NLP methods, and NLP researchers were largely unaware that "natural" software had similar statistical characteristics to natural language.

We worked together develop better joint understanding of the problems in software engineering, and how NLP methods could be applied. We had several teleconferences, and also one joint meeting at Davis during the summer of 2013. This helped us develop further directions of research. Dana Movshovits-Attias, PhD student at CMU, developed methods to recover facts from software documents, and also methods to assist programmers create code documents. The work led to the forumulation of several new promising research problems, including for example the use of statistical natural language translation methods for code porting.

Results: At Davis, with Postdoc Zhaopeng Tu) we noticed that  the vocabulary in code was much larger, because code tended to constantly introduce new variable names; however, we also noticed that variables tended to be reused in local context, in a contextually repetitive fashion. 

Based on this observation, we developed statistical language models that captured both local and global repetitiveness, using a type of dynamic on-line mixture model, which mixed the estimated probabilities from local and global contexts. This model is general significantly outperformed the default model that we had been using, in terms of the usual information-theoretic measure of cross-entropy. In addition, we also found much better performance on tasks such as code completion, and defect localization. The former has led to downloadable tools for code suggestion in Java, and one Python which we hope to release shortly. THe latter work is still ongoing.

Continuation: The collaborations that we could establish using the EAGER funding has to a much broader definition of a research agenda, which has led to a  SHF CISE  LARGE project toegether with CMU and Iowa State.
